text: The film shows the mundane life of a commander of Auschwitz  Rudolph Hess (Christian Friedel), his wife Hedwig (Sandra Huller), and their 5 children living in a sprawling estate next to a concentration camp. In spite of the distant faint gunshots, screams, train noises which are no doubt from the frequent exterminations in the camp, the Hess family along with the maids, gardeners who work in the house try to maintain normalcy.  This movie reminds of the 1970 film The Garden of the Finzi-Continis where it also depicted an opulent family's mundane life in their estate at the outset of WW2 except they're Jewish and movie ends with the family getting sent to the concentration camp. The Hess family here is also headed to their doom with the eventual death of Hitler and the downfall of the Nazis. The movie is at times too static or subtle, but reading throught plot details of the movie shows how the scenes are truly unnerving!

author: @onegathers
text:
Just been to the cinema to see 'Zone of interest', the latest film by the brilliant Jonathan Glazer, whose Under the skin was my favourite film of 2013.
Telling the story of Höss, kommandant of Auschwitz-Birkenau extermination camp, and the idyllic life he has with his children and horses in the house built next to the death camp. Much of the film concerns banal incidents, his socially ambitious wife showing guests around her house while Polish servants scurry out of her way. 
What is extraordinary however is the sound design of the film. Below the everyday chit chat are a low, endless and menacing drone, with screams, guard dogs, gun fire, trains arriving, yells in German a constant background of unspeakable horror.
Höss comes across in the film like he came across in the book he wrote waiting for the hangman: caring for his own children while murdering other people's children daily in their thousands, uncaring and aloof...in his book he slags off all his fellow SS, doing them no favours in their upcoming trials.
And extraordinary experience, one that echoes Hannah Arendt's description of Eichmann: the banality of evil.

This movie is long overdue. Don´t get me wrong. I am not "hating" on Germans who live in 2024 and I am NOT blaming them for what their ancestors did ++80 years ago. I haven´t watched the movie yet - but I have heard and read a lot about it. The movie raises an important question: How much did the "normal" German citizen know about the Concentration camps? It is VERY difficult to believe that basically and allegedly no Germans knew about the Concentration camps and what happened inside them. People must have been wondering how thousands of railroad waggons could arrive with people and no railroad waggon ever left the place again with people. People must have been wondering what happened to those people who arrived in railroad waggons. The local people near the Concentration camps worked in those camps. Don´t tell me they did NOT know what happened.

I live in a Scandinavian country. I have several friends in Germany. Among them a 73 year old woman - born in 1950, so she wasn´t alive when all this happened. However. I found it difficult to believe when she told me last time she visited me: *_"My parents, and the Germans in general did not know what was going on in the concentration camps"_* - Like I said - I find that VERY hard to believe - and research done by reputable historians has also concluded that many Germans very well knew what happened there.

My point is: Germans who claim that the broad German population did not know about this - are simply not telling the truth. Germans who lived back then had a RESPONSIBILITY for doing something against those atrocities. Doing nothing and being totally passive when atrocities like these happen is NEVER a legitimate reason to say: "I was not guilty - I did not put those jews into gas chambers". YES - you are also guilty if you don´t react to atrocities and stay passive. It is beyond my imagination how some Germans could work in the concentration camps during daytime - look at hundred thousands or "prisoners" who were basically "skin and bones" and who clearly suffered - and they must also have seen how many people died. They watched how many people got tortured. They saw how there were kids there suffering - and many of those kids also died. 

And many of those Germans who saw all these atrocities and crimes against humanity on a daily basis - they then after work went home to their families - had a barbeque and cake and played in the garden with their kids, like ABSOLUTELY nothing had happened.
